data.question: What is the main focus of the research conducted by Eugenia Peresypkina and colleagues?
data.answer: The main focus of the research is on three-component self-assembly reactions leading to the formation of 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers and unprecedented 3D networks of nano-sized host–guest assemblies.

data.question: What is the borderline dinitrile backbone length for switching the self-assembly system?
data.answer: The seven-membered backbone of the dinitrile is the borderline for switching the self-assembly system.

data.question: What types of structures are formed when the dinitrile backbone length is less than 7?
data.answer: When the dinitrile backbone length is less than 7, various rather simple polymers are formed, possessing either 0D or 1D Ag/A structural motifs.

data.question: What happens to the self-assembly system when the dinitrile backbone length is 7 or greater?
data.answer: When the dinitrile backbone length is 7 or greater, the self-assembly switches to forming extraordinary 3D networks of nano-sized host–guest assemblies.

data.question: Are the polycationic nodes based on A and silver host–guest able?
data.answer: Yes, the polycationic nodes represent the first superspheres based on A and silver and are host–guest able.

data.question: What techniques were used to characterize the products?
data.answer: The products were characterized by NMR spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

data.question: What is the significance of the 56-vertex polycationic host–guest assembly?
data.answer: The 56-vertex polycationic host–guest assembly represents a novel class of 3D supramolecular coordination polymers with potential for host–guest chemistry applications.

data.question: Is the formation of simple coordination polymers observed with dinitriles having a backbone length of 8 to 10?
data.answer: No, with dinitriles having a backbone length of 8 to 10, the formation of simple coordination polymers was not observed.

data.question: What is the outer diameter of the spherical cationic assembly mentioned in the research?
data.answer: The outer diameter of the spherical cationic assembly is 2.21 nm.

data.question: Can the supramolecular coordination polymers be stored without degradation?
data.answer: Yes, the supramolecular coordination polymers do not show decomposition when stored in a glovebox and can be kept under mother liquor solution for six months or longer.

data.question: What happens to the self-assembly system when exposed to air?
data.answer: When exposed to air, or upon changes of mother liquor solution composition, a degradation of the supramolecular coordination polymers takes place.

data.question: What is the role of the weakly coordinating anion SbF6@ in the self-assembly process?
data.answer: The weakly coordinating anion SbF6@ plays a crucial role in facilitating the formation of polycationic nodes and enabling the self-assembly process.

data.question: Are the resulting supramolecular coordination polymers soluble in common solvents?
data.answer: No, the resulting supramolecular coordination polymers are insoluble in hexane, toluene, CH2Cl2, thf, and Et2O.

data.question: What is the effect of the dinitrile backbone length on the self-assembly system?
data.answer: The dinitrile backbone length significantly influences the self-assembly system, determining whether simple polymers or 3D networks of nano-sized host–guest assemblies are formed.

data.question: What is the significance of the research conducted by Eugenia Peresypkina and colleagues?
data.answer: The research opens up new perspectives in the design and synthesis of 3D supramolecular coordination polymers with potential applications in host–guest chemistry.

data.question: Is the formation of 3D supramolecular coordination polymers dependent on the presence of additional stimuli?
data.answer: No, the formation of 3D supramolecular coordination polymers does not require additional stimuli, as the system self-assembles into these structures.

data.question: What is the impact of the research on the field of supramolecular chemistry?
data.answer: The research significantly contributes to the field of supramolecular chemistry by demonstrating a novel approach to constructing 3D supramolecular coordination polymers.

data.question: What potential applications do the 3D supramolecular coordination polymers have?
data.answer: The 3D supramolecular coordination polymers have potential applications in chemosensing, drug delivery, and controlled absorption due to their host–guest chemistry capabilities.

data.question: What is the role of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) in the research?
data.answer: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to visualize the nano-sized organometallic Ag-based spherical aggregates, demonstrating the formation of the supramolecular structures.

data.question: What future directions does the research suggest for the development of supramolecular coordination polymers?
data.answer: The research suggests exploring targeted guest encapsulation and tailoring the structure and properties of the supramolecular nodes for specific applications as future directions.
